== Personal life == Fripp married [[Toyah Willcox]] in 1986 in [[Poole]], Dorset, England.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.findmypast.com/BirthsMarriagesDeaths.jsp |title=Marriages England and Wales 1984–2005 |publisher=Findmypast.com |accessdate=19 February 2012}}</ref> From December 1987 until July 1999 they lived at and renovated [[Reddish House]], the former home of [[Cecil Beaton]], in [[Broad Chalke]] Wiltshire.<ref name=RF>{{cite web | title=Robert Fripp's diary for Wednesday 4th April 2007| work=Robert Fripp's diary| url=http://www.dgmlive.com/<!-- /diaries.htm?entry=13491 -->| accessdate=9 November 2008}}</ref><ref name="Broad">Broad Chalke, A History of a South Wiltshire Village, its Land & People Over 2,000 years. By 'The People of the Village', 1999</ref> At present his home is in [[Pershore]], Worcestershire.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.192.com/people/search/?&surname=Fripp&location=Pershore&page=1&searchType=PeopleSimple|title=Fripp in Pershore - UK address and phone number - 192.com|publisher=}}</ref> The couple have no children and have arranged their will so as to leave their entire fortune to the establishment of a musical educational trust for children.<ref> {{ cite web | accessdate = 4 April 2017 | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-1026134/Toyah-Willcox-Ive-facelift--I-want-tummy-tuck-boobs-removed-I-bear-them.html | newspaper = [[Daily Mail]] | title = Toyah Willcox: I've had a facelift... now I want a tummy tuck and my boobs removed because I can't bear them | publicationdate = 13 June 2008 | first = Lester | last = Middlehurst }} </ref>
Fripp is the patron of the Seattle Circle Guitar School and the Shallal Dance Theatre in Penzance, England.<ref name="SCGS"/> He also has had engagements as a [[motivational speaker]], often at events with his sister Patricia,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://robertfrippspeaks.com/robertfrippinterview.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120718061718/http://robertfrippspeaks.com/robertfrippinterview.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=18 July 2012 |title=Robert Fripp Speaking Engagements – articles, interviews and links |publisher=Robertfrippspeaks.com |date=19 February 2008 |accessdate=19 February 2012 }}</ref> who is a [[keynote speaker]] and speech coach.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fripp.com/ |title=Patricia Fripp & Associates: Experts in Presentation Skills |publisher=Fripp.com |date=4 June 1912 |accessdate=19 February 2012}}</ref>
[[Alfie Fripp]], the last of the "39ers", shot down by the [[Luftwaffe]] and then held in 12 different POW camps during [[World War II]], was his uncle.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dgmlive.com/diaries.htm?artist=&show=&member=3&entry=22739|first=Robert|last=Fripp|title=Robert Fripp's Diary for Sunday, 11th November 2012|website=DGMLive.com|accessdate=4 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140111131245/http://www.dgmlive.com/diaries.htm?artist=&show=&member=3&entry=22739|archivedate=11 January 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Fripp is a [[pescetarian]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.dgmlive.com/diaries/Robert%20Fripp/vegetarian-restaurant-of-wonder-and-210916|title= Robert Fripp's Diary|date=2 July 2003|quote=Nowadays I accept that, properly put, I am a fishetarian...|accessdate= 9 August 2016|location=Barcelona, Spain|website=DGMLive.com|first=Robert|last=Fripp|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402173233/http://dgmlive.com/diaries.htm?entry=622|archivedate=2 April 2015}}</ref>
==Discipline Global Mobile== {{Main|Discipline Global Mobile}}
In 1992, Fripp and producer/online content developer David Singleton co-founded [[Discipline Global Mobile]] (DGM) as an [[independent record label|independent music label]]. DGM releases music by Fripp, KC, related acts, and other artists in CDs and in downloadable files. A 1998 ''Billboard'' profile stated that DGM had ten staff-members in [[Salisbury]] (England) and Los Angeles (USA). DGM has an aim "to be a model of ethical business in an industry founded on exploitation, oiled by deceit, riven with theft and fueled by greed."<ref name="FrippInBruns"> {{harvtxt|Fripp|1998|p=9}} : {{cite book|last=Fripp|first=Robert|chapter=Discipline Global Mobile: A small, mobile and independent record company|type=CD booklet|title=[[Space Groove]]|others=[[ProjeKcts#ProjeKct Two (1997–1998)|ProjeKct Two]]|publisher=[[Discipline Global Mobile]]|year=1998|pages=9–10|ref=harv|id={{Allmusic | class =album | id = r346912 | tab = | label = Space Groove | accessdate =29 February 2012}} [[Stock-keeping unit|Sku]] DGM9801. Cited by {{harvtxt|Bruns|2003|p=3}}|chapter-url=https://www.dgmlive.com}}{{Bad linked references|section|date=January 2013}} {{cite journal|last=Bruns|first=Axel|title=Fight for survival: The RIAA's sustained attack on streaming media|journal=M/C: A Journal of Media and Culture|volume=6|year=2003 |url=http://eprints.qut.edu.au/192/1/Bruns_Fight.PDF|ref=harv|format=PDF|id="RIAA" abbreviates "[[Recording Industry Association of America]]"|pages=1–6|issue=1}} </ref> DGM insists that its artists retain all copyrights; consequently, even DGM's "knotwork" corporate-logo ''(pictured above)'' is owned by its designer,<ref>{{cite book|last=Fripp|first=Robert|<!-- authorlink=Robert Fripp -->|type=Liner notes|chapter=CD booklet|pages=3 and 17|title=[[Absent Lovers: Live in Montreal]]|others=[[King Crimson#King Crimson, line-up 4 (1981–1984)|King Crimson]]|publisher=Discipline Global Mobile|chapter-url=https://www.dgmlive.com|year=1998a|ref=harv|id=[[Stock-keeping unit|Sku]] DGM9804. {{Allmusic | class =album | id = r365425 | tab = | label = Absent Lovers | accessdate =29 February 2012}}}}{{Bad linked references|section|date=January 2013}}</ref> Steve Ball;<ref name="HHcredits" >{{harvtxt|Hegarty|Halliwell|2011|loc=[http://cipg.codemantra.us/UI_TRANSACTIONS/Marketing/UI_Marketing.aspx?ID=WP9780826423320&ISBN=9780826423320&sts=b "Illustration credits: Chapter 9", p. xii]}} </ref> the "knotwork" logo appeared earlier on the cover of later versions of the ''Discipline'' album. DGM's aims were called "exemplary" by {{harvtxt|Martin|1997}}, who wrote that "Fripp has done something very important for the possibilities of experimental music" in creating DGM, which "has played a major role in creating favorable conditions for" King Crimson.<ref name="Martin269">{{harvtxt|Martin|1997|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=APmUFlgm0R4C&dq=Prog+Rock&q=Discipline+Global+Mobile#v=snippet&q=Discipline%20Global%20Mobile&f=false 269]}}</ref>
DGM publishes an on-line diary by Fripp, who often comments on performances and on relations with fans. A moderated forum allows fans to ask questions or to leave comments. Together, Fripp's diary and the fan forum display delayed dialogs in which Fripp and fans discuss diary-entries and forum-postings.<ref name="Atton43"/>
===Copyright complaints against Grooveshark===
{{main|Grooveshark}}
In 2011, Fripp complained that the music-distribution service [[Grooveshark]] continued to stream his music despite his having delivered repeated [[notice and take down|takedown notice]]s. Fripp and Grooveshark's correspondence was published by ''Digital Music News''<ref name="NYT14Dec11"/><ref>{{cite news|title=Grooveshark lawsuit reveals details of Universal Music Group's allegations|first=Glenn|last=Peoples|date=21 November 2011|newspaper=Billboard.biz|url=http://www.billboard.biz/bbbiz/industry/legal-and-management/grooveshark-lawsuit-reveals-details-of-universal-1005549582.story|ref=harv|accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="DMN">{{cite journal|title=King Crimson can't get their music off of Grooveshark, so they cc'd ''Digital Music News''|date=13 October 2011|ref=harv|url=http://www.digitalmusicnews.com/stories/101311cc|first=Paul ("paul")|last=Resnikoff|journal=[[Digital Music News]]|accessdate=30 May 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111123003659/http://www.digitalmusicnews.com/stories/101311cc|archivedate=23 November 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and in his diaries,<ref name="Fripp" >{{cite web|title=Robert Fripp's diaries|url=http://www.dgmlive.com<!-- /diaries.htm?entry=13491 -->|ref=harv|date=12 August – 20 October 2011 |publisher=[[Discipline Global Mobile]], DMG Live!|first=Robert|last=Fripp|accessdate=30 May 2012<!-- authorlink=Robert Fripp -->}}: <!-- DGM's Terms of Service prohibit linking to internal pages, e.g. this diary's entry, without explicit permission; thus search strings are provided --><br /><br />August: "Friday, 12th August 2011", "Saturday, 13th August 2011", "Monday, 15th August 2011", "Tuesday, 16th August 2011", "Wednesday, 17th August 2011";<br /><br />September: "Wednesday, 7th September 2011", "Saturday, 10th September 2011", "Monday, 12th September 2011", "Wednesday, 14th September 2011", "Thursday, 15th September 2011", "Wednesday, 21 September 2011", and "Monday, 26th September 2011";<br /><br />October: "Thursday, October 13th, 2011" and "Thursday, 20th October 2011". {{Bad linked references|section|date=January 2013}} </ref> which appear on the website of Discipline Global Mobile.<ref name="Atton43" >{{harvtxt|Atton|2001|p=43}}: {{cite journal|first=Chris|last=Atton|journal=Popular Music|year=2001|volume=20|pages=29–46|publisher=Cambridge University Press|doi=10.1017/S0261143001001295|title='Living in the Past'?: Value discourses in progressive rock fanzines|jstor=853693|ref=harv}}</ref>
Fripp's published exchange was included in a suit against Grooveshark by Universal Music Group, which was filed in November 2011.<ref name="NYT14Dec11" >{{cite news|title=Sony and Warner are said to sue web music service|first=Ben|last=Sisario|date=14 December 2011|newspaper=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/15/business/media/sony-and-warner-are-said-to-join-suit-against-grooveshark.html?_r=1|ref=harv|accessdate=30 May 2012}}</ref><ref name="Sandoval"/> UMG cited internal documents revealing that Grooveshark employees uploaded thousands of illegal copies of UMG-owned recordings.<ref name="Sandoval">[http://news.cnet.com/8301-31001_3-57327815-261/lawsuit-claims-grooveshark-workers-posted-100000-pirated-songs/ Lawsuit claims Grooveshark workers posted 100,000 pirated songs]. Greg Sandoval, CNET, 21 November 2011</ref> Fripp had previous experience protecting his music in litigation with music companies.<ref>{{harvtxt|Bruford|2009|p=[https://books.google.com/books?hl=sv&id=R4iW0tsxLqQC&dq=Bill+Bruford&q=EG%2C%20Virgin%2C%20EMI%2C%20Fripp&f=false#v=snippet&q=EG%2C%20Virgin%2C%20EMI%2C%20Fripp&f=false 142]}}: {{cite book|title=Bill Bruford: The autobiography: Yes, King Crimson, Earthworks, and more|first=Bill|last=Bruford|authorlink=Bill Bruford|publisher=Jawbone Press|year=2009|isbn=978-1-906002-23-7|ref=harv}}</ref>
==Discography== {{Main|Robert Fripp discography}} {{See also|King Crimson discography}} Fripp has been extremely active as a recording musician and a producer. He has contributed to more than 700 official releases. The Robert Fripp Discography Summary, compiled by John Relph, also lists 120 compilations and 315 unauthorised releases (such as [[Bootleg recording|bootlegs]]). This means that more than 1100 releases (including both official and unofficial ones, as well as both studio and live recordings) can be found with Fripp participating. [[File:Shoro nagashi 20100815195412.png|thumb|250px|A boat being pushed in Gotōmachi.]] The {{nihongo|'''Spirit Boat Procession'''|精霊流し|Shōrō nagashi}} is an event celebrated in various places in [[Nagasaki prefecture]], [[Japan]]. It is part of the [[Bon Festival]]. During the event, the souls of the deceased are mourned and sent off.
== Description == The procession takes place on August 15 of every year. During the procession, people float boats which are said to be carrying the spirits of the deceased down the river. The spirits are said to be sent to [[Sukhavati]].<ref name="shoubai">{{cite book|last=泉秀樹|title=商売繁盛・老舗のしきたり|year=2008|publisher=PHP研究所|isbn=4-569-70013-6|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1_HdsTFBNCMC&pg=PA35&dq=%E7%B2%BE%E9%9C%8A%E6%B5%81%E3%81%97&hl=en&ei=vB51TIbzD4H-8AaewvSNBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCQQ6AEwADgK#v=onepage&q=%E7%B2%BE%E9%9C%8A%E6%B5%81%E3%81%97&f=false}}</ref> It is done as an act of mourning by those who have lost a family member in the past year, though people who are not mourning participate as well.
As with many other Japanese festivals, people carry firecrackers and gongs, and often sound off with [[kakegoe]]. Some boats are built up to look like festival floats, and many tourists come to see the event. Despite the atmosphere, the procession is actually a Buddhist event of mourning the deceased. At one time the boats were floated off into the ocean, but in recent years the boats are retrieved before they go out that far so as to prevent polluting the ocean.<ref name="utsukushii">{{cite book|title=美しい日本の習慣 |year=2008|publisher=PHP研究所|isbn=4-569-66958-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=M2DLzKzyLbUC&pg=PA91&dq=%E7%B2%BE%E9%9C%8A%E6%B5%81%E3%81%97&hl=en&ei=9xx1TO2bN4H_8Ab7koHIBw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&ved=0CDgQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%E7%B2%BE%E9%9C%8A%E6%B5%81%E3%81%97&f=false}}</ref>
In 2010, it was reported that more than 180,000 people had attended the event.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nagasaki-np.co.jp/kiji/20100817/02.shtml|title=県内精霊流し人出18万6000人 昨年比1万6000人増|accessdate=25 August 2010|newspaper=Journal Nagasaki|date=18 August 2010|quote="約１８万６千人" - around 186,000 people"}}</ref>
=== Boats === The boats are called {{nihongo|''shōrōbune''|精霊船}}.<ref>{{cite book|last=Rogers|first=J. Earl |title=The art of grief|year=2007|publisher=CRC Press|isbn=0-415-95535-1|pages=131|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CBjbsj3cPtEC&pg=PA131&dq=shoro+nagashi&hl=en&ei=JZtsTOLQEsH38AadtO2eCw&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCUQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=shoro%20nagashi&f=false}}</ref> The boats are said to carry the souls of the deceased on them. The boats are mainly built by people who have lost a family member in the last year, though they are also built by others.
The boats can be built from a quantity of different supplies and no particular one is preferred. Bamboo and grass are often used,<ref name="shoubai"/> though [[cogongrass]] is popular in [[Saikai, Nagasaki]],<ref>[http://www.nagasaki-np.co.jp/kiji/20100814/06.shtml チガヤや竹で精霊船作り 西海・柳地区、お盆の伝統脈々]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} - 長崎新聞</ref> and some other people use hardened corrugated cardboard. People who are mourning decorate the boat with the family crest, put a portrait of the deceased and the mortuary tablet on the boat, and also sometimes use a token that exemplifies the person (e.g. a shogi player may have a shogi piece on the boat). Those who are not mourning generally build small laced rafts, and set O-Bon lanterns, fruit or non-natural flowers on them instead. Boats made by individuals or family members are generally between 1 and 2 meters. Often boats also have a sail with [[sutra]]s for Buddha and Kannon.<ref name="utsukushii"/>
Larger boats, called ''moyaibune'', are created and sent out by neighborhoods, local councils or organizations. Prior to the 1950s, these sorts of boats were more popular, as individual family boats are expensive and considered relatively luxurious. Neighborhood boats are usually adorned with the town icon, and paper lanterns with family crests are hung off the boat.
In more recent years, less traditional boats have gained popularity. These boats are discussed to as {{nihongo|''kawari shorobune''|変わり精霊船}} and are becoming progressively popular. An example of such a boat would be a yacht-shaped boat for someone who was an avid sailor.
== Origin == There are various theories as to the festival's origin, though it is believed to be strongly influenced by a similar Chinese festival. The meaning of the firecrackers that are fired on the side of the road leading up to the launching place comes from a Chinese idea on how to ward off evil spirits, and by passing the boats by, they are cleansed.
== Song == [[Masashi Sada]], a native of Nagasaki, wrote a song called ''Shoro nagashi'' that is essentially about the festival. It was recorded along with Masami Yoshida under the band name ''Grape'' and was released in 1974. At the end of 2009 Sada's father died, and in 2010 he and his family sailed a boat in honor of his father.<ref>{{cite news|title=長崎で精霊流し、「父送る」さださんも参加|url=https://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=ja&tl=en&u=http%3A%2F%2Fkyushu.yomiuri.co.jp%2Fnews%2Fnational%2F20100816-OYS1T00572.htm|accessdate=25 August 2010|newspaper=Yomiuri|date=16 August 2010}}</ref> Footage was broadcast around the country.

[[Image:Tombawcockseve.jpg|thumb|right|200px|The lantern parade for Tom Bawcock's Eve]] '''Tom Bawcock's Eve''' is an annual festival, held on 23 December, in [[Mousehole]], [[Cornwall]], England.
The festival is held in celebration and memorial of the efforts of legendary Mousehole resident [[Tom Bawcock]] to lift a famine from the village by going out to fish in a severe storm. During this festival [[Stargazy pie]] (a mixed fish, egg and potato pie with protruding fish heads) is eaten and depending on the year of celebration a lantern procession takes place.
== Origins == There are several theories of the origins of this festival, but the first recorded description was made by [[Robert Morton Nance]] in 1927 in the magazine ''Old Cornwall''. Nance described the festival as it existed around the start of the 20th century. Within this work Nance also speculated that the name Bawcock was derived from Beau Coq ([[French language|French]]) - he believed the cock was a herald of new light in [[Pagan]] times and the origins of the festival were pre-Christian. The most likely derivation of the name 'Bawcock' is from [[Middle English]] use (influenced by French) where a Bawcock is a nickname for a fine or worthy fellow. An example of such use can be found in Shakespeare's ''[[Twelfth Night]]'' Act 3. Scene 4: "Why, how now, my bawcock!" As the name Tom was often used as a generic description for any man it is likely that Tom Bawcock was a symbolic name for 'any fine fellow' who risked his life in pursuit of fishing. [[Midwinter]] celebrations were also common in one of Cornwall's other principal traditional occupations [[mining]]. [[Picrous Day]] and [[Chewidden Thursday]] seem to have similar origins to Tom Bawcock's Eve. The only similar tradition in the British Isles that can be traced is [[Rumwold of Buckingham|St Rumbold]]s night at [[Folkestone]] in Kent. This celebration also took place near Christmas time<ref>http://www.folkestonetriennial.org.uk/history/sarah-staton/</ref> where eight [[Merlangius|Whiting]]s were offered in a feast to celebrate St Rumbold<ref>http://www.coastalheritage.org.uk/Saint%20Rumbold.htm</ref> In Italy a Christmas Eve feast including fishes is called 'Il Cenone' or 'Big Dinner' or sometimes 'Cena della Vigilia' ([[Christmas Eve#Italy|the dinner of the vigil]]). Today the observance the feast of the Vigil is rarely practised in Italy but it survives in [[Italian Americans|Italian American]] households, where it is better known as the [[Feast of the Seven Fishes]].
== ''The Mousehole Cat'' == The children's book ''[[The Mousehole Cat]]'' by [[Antonia Barber]] was inspired by the traditions and practice of Tom Bawcock's Eve and resulted in a television production of the same name. (Ms Barber lists Star-Gazy Pie as a staple of Mousehole diet ''before'' Tom's heroic fishing expedition, however, whereas according to tradition it dates from his return and legendary catch.)
== Folk music traditions == There is an ongoing folk music tradition associated with Tom Bawcock's Eve. The words were written by Robert Morton Nance in 1927, to a traditional local tune called the 'Wedding March'. It is believed that Nance first observed the festivities around the start of the 20th century. His version runs as follows: {| class="wikitable" |+ Side by side comparison !The original wording !The poem in modern English |- |<poem>A merry plaas you may believe woz Mowsel pon Tom Bawcock's Eve. To be theer then oo wudn wesh To sup o sibm soorts o fesh!
Wen morgee brath ad cleard tha path Comed lances for a fry, An then us had a bet o scad an starry gazee py.
Nex cumd fermaads, braa thustee jaads As maad ar oozles dry, An ling an haak, enough to maak a raunen shark to sy!
A aech wed clunk as ealth wer drunk En bumpers bremmen y, An wen up caam Tom Bawcock's naam We praesed un to tha sky.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cooksinfo.com/tom-bawcocks-eve |title=Tom Bawcock's Eve |publisher=CooksInfo.com |date=11 June 2009 |accessdate=15 November 2017 }}</ref> </poem>|| <poem>A merrier place you may believe Was Mousehole on Tom Bawcock's eve To be there then who wouldn't wish To sup on seven sorts of fish
When murgy broth had cleared the path Comed lances for a fry And then us had a bit o' scad And starry gazey pie
Next comed fair maids, bra' thrusty jades As made our oozles dry And ling and hake, enough to make A running shark to sigh
As each we'd clunk as health were drunk In bumpers brimming high And when up came Tom Bawcock's name We praised him to the sky.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nance|first1=Robert Norton|journal=Old Cornwall Journal|date=1927}}</ref> </poem> |}
The dialect used in the words of the song translate as follows:- * 'Morgy' = Morgey is still the term used in Cornwall and Scotland for [[Small-spotted catshark|Dogfish]] * 'Lances' = Sometimes 'Launces' [[Sand eels]] * Rauning/Running = Hungry or Ravenous <ref>{{cite book|last1=Wright|first1=Joseph|title=The English dialect dictionary, being the complete vocabulary of all dialect words still in use, or known to have been in use during the last two hundred years|isbn=5880963039|page=53}}</ref> * 'Scad' = [[Atlantic horse mackerel|Horse Mackerel]] <ref>http://britishseafishing.co.uk/scad/</ref> * 'Fair Maids' = Smoked [[Sardine|Pilchards]] - a corruption of 'formade', from the Spanish word 'fumade' or smoked.<ref>https://www.thefreedictionary.com/Fumade</ref> * 'bra' thrusty jades' = Bra' is short for 'brave' and 'Jade' is an old word used in England and Scotland to mean 'Wild young woman'<ref>{{cite book|last1=Wilson|first1=James|title=The dialect of Robert Burns|publisher=Oxford University Press|page=171|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=YFCNBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA171&dq=jade+dialect+for+woman&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwinnfjctb7XAhUMB8AKHaBUBl4Q6AEINDAC#v=onepage&q=jade%20dialect%20for%20woman&f=false}}</ref> * 'Oozles' = Throats (windpipes)<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/devon/voices2005/features/pop_o.shtml</ref> * 'Clunk' = to swallow<ref>http://www.bbc.co.uk/history/domesday/dblock/GB-196000-57000/page/14</ref> * Bumpers = large glass, full to overflowing <ref>https://blog.oup.com/2012/12/drinking-vessel-bumper-etymology-word-origin/</ref>
The song appears on four of the albums by Cornish singer [[Brenda Wootton]]: ''Piper's Folk'' (1968), ''Starry Gazey Pie'' (1975), ''Way Down to Lamorna'' (1984) and ''Voice of Cornwall'' (1996).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brendawootton.eu/storepage1776509.aspx |title=Brenda Wootton: Complete Discography |publisher=Brendawootton.eu |date= |accessdate=26 October 2015}}</ref>

'''VIEW Conference''' is a [[computer graphics]] event in [[Italy]] and is held yearly in [[Turin]], between October and November. Topics represented at the event include interactive techniques, digital cinema, 3D animation, gaming and VFX.
The event spans several days and includes sessions open to the public. The conference includes several international speakers from various sectors within the computer graphics field who present their work to the attendees as well as ''Master Classes'' and theory lessons taught by experts.<ref name=stamp>{{cite news|last1=Alessandra C.|title=Con un poker View Conference è da Oscar|url=http://www.lastampa.it/2011/10/24/tecnologia/view/2011/con-un-poker-viewconferencee-da-oscar-Rqf57PrAyUgkW8T3o89bPJ/pagina.html|accessdate=2 October 2016|work=[[La Stampa]]|date=24 October 2011}}</ref>
== History ==
The event was created in 2000 as ''Virtuality Conference''.<ref name=stamp/> It changed its name for its eighth edition, in 2007, adopting the acronym ''VIEW'', meaning "Virtual Interactive Emerging World".<ref name=repub>{{cite news|last1=Jamie D'Alessandro|title=Torino, ecco View Conference I maghi della computer grafica|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2005/i/sezioni/scienza_e_tecnologia/videogiochi/view-torino/view-torino.html|accessdate=2 October 2016|work=[[La Repubblica]]|date=6 November 2007}}</ref> The content of the conference has changed and evolved over the years as well. While still focusing on "virtual reality", the VIEW Conference now includes emerging digital technology and applications including animation, special effects, virtual architecture, and videogames. Speakers of the various editions include [[Grant Major]],<ref name=repub/> [[Scott Farrar]],<ref name=stamp/> [[Roger Guyett]],<ref name=stamp/> [[John Knoll]],<ref name="busi">{{cite news|last1=Candido Romano|title=VIEW Conference 2013: a Torino le meraviglie dell'animazione, videogiochi ed effetti speciali|url=http://it.ibtimes.com/view-conference-2013-torino-le-meraviglie-dellanimazione-videogiochi-ed-effetti-speciali-1342675#|accessdate=2 October 2016|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=16 October 2013}}</ref> [[Alvy Ray Smith]],<ref name="auto">{{cite news|last1=Jennifer Wolfe|title=VIEW Conference Announces 2014 Keynote Speakers|url=http://www.awn.com/news/view-conference-announces-2014-keynote-speakers|accessdate=2 October 2016|work=[[Animation World Network|AWN]]|date=25 August 2014}}</ref> [[Glen Keane]],<ref name="auto"/> [[Byron Howard]],<ref name=var>{{cite news|last1=Terry Flores|title=‘Zootopia’ Co-Director Byron Howard Among View Conference Keynote Speakers|url=https://variety.com/2016/biz/news/zootopia-byron-howard-view-conference-speaker-1201830032/|accessdate=2 October 2016|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|date=4 August 2016}}</ref> [[Brad Lewis]],<ref name=var/> [[Walter Murch]],<ref>{{cite news|last1=Terry Flores|title=‘Apocalypse Now’ Editor Walter Murch Added to View Conference Lineup|url=https://variety.com/2015/biz/news/view-conference-walter-much-godfather-1201622380/|accessdate=2 October 2016|work=Variety|date=20 October 2015 }}</ref> [[Mike Mitchell (director)|Mike Mitchell]] and [[Walt Dohrn]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Terry Flores|title=‘Trolls’ Directors Mike Mitchell, Walt Dohrn Added to VIEW Conference 2016 Lineup|url=https://variety.com/2016/film/global/trolls-directors-view-conference-1201861829/|accessdate=2 October 2016|work=Variety|date=15 September 2016}}</ref>
In 2005 the VIEW Conference established the "VIEW Award", an international award for [[3D computer graphics|3D]] animated and VFX [[short film]]s, targeted to students, artists and filmmakers. As of 2016 the award has five categories, Best Short, VIEW Social Contest ( aimed at involving visual artists, designers and computer graphics lovers with works using 2D/3D animation and/or VFX focusing on themes of social relevance), View Game Award, VIEWTube Video Award and Italianmix.<ref name=var/> Winners are selected by an international jury composed of experts in the different disciplines of the contest and by teachers and school directors from animation schools in Europe and North America.
==VIEW Fest== '''VIEW Fest''' is an international [[film festival]] held annually in Turin, Italy between October and November which focuses on Italian filmmakers, digital artists, and other creative professionals. The VIEWFest includes a short film competition called ITALIANMIX, which accepts short films from all visual forms from both students and non-students featuring new technology and techniques. The VIEWFest occurs directly after the VIEW Conference as the second portion of the event in which screenings of new digital films and media take place.

{{Infobox event | title = World Youth Day 1984 | image = | image_size = | caption = | date = {{start date|1984|04|14}} – {{end date|1984|04|15}} | time = | type = Youth festival | theme = Aperite portas Redemptoris | venue = | place = [[Vatican City]] | coordinates = | organisers = [[Catholic Church]] | participants = [[Pope John Paul II]] | website = }} '''World Youth Day 1984''' was an international meeting promoted by [[Pope John Paul II]] at the extraordinary [[Jubilee (Christianity)| Holy Year]] of the Redemption. It was the first large youth gathering promoted by the [[Catholic Church]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vatican.va/roman_curia/pontifical_councils/laity/Colonia2005/rc_pc_laity_doc_20030805_cross-history-gmg_sp.html|title=JMJ 2005 - La peregrinación de la Cruz de los Jóvenes (1984-2014)|website=www.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> From that experience came the idea of the [[World Youth Day]]s which since then have been held, every two or three years, in different countries of the world.
The meeting with the Pope took place in [[Rome]] on Saturday, April 14, 1984 before [[Palm Sunday]]. The young people found themselves in the morning in the square in front of the [[Archbasilica of St. John Lateran| Basilica of Saint John Lateran]] for mass, then a long procession went to [[St. Peter's Square]] in the [[Vatican City|Vatican]] where the meeting took place with the Pope who, for the occasion, was accompanied on stage created on the steps of [[St. Peter's Basilica]] by [[Mother Teresa of Calcutta]].
About 300,000 people attended the meeting, mostly Italians, but with a significant presence of young people coming from abroad.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071211155616/http://www.wjt2005.de/index.php@id=161&si=4.htm|title=Sito web ufficiale della XX GMG 2005: Storia delle Giornate Mondiali della Gioventù|date=11 December 2007|publisher=|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref><ref>There were 400,000 participants according to the newspaper Avvenire (source ANSA, in Pino Vicentini, The Revolution in a Day, in Avvenire, Friday 11 August 2000.)</ref> Pope John Paul II concluded the Youth Jubilee during the angelus of Palm Sunday.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://w2.vatican.va/content/john-paul-ii/it/angelus/1984/documents/hf_jp-ii_ang_19840415.html|title=Angelus, 15 aprile 1984, Domenica delle Palme - Giovanni Paolo II|website=w2.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref> The next day, the Pope concluded the Jubilee of the Youth with the [[angelus]] on Palm Sunday.
The following week, on Easter Sunday, April 22, 1984, the Pope gave the youth the Cross of the World Youth Day as a symbol of "the love of the Lord Jesus for humanity and as an announcement that only in Christ died and resurrected it is salvation and redemption." On this occasion he renewed the appointment for a meeting with the young people for Palm Sunday next, March 31, 1985, in the year that the UN proclaimed International Year of Youth.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://w2.vatican.va/content/john-paul-ii/it/speeches/1984/april/documents/hf_jp-ii_spe_19840422_cross-youth.html|title=Ai giovani (22 aprile 1984) - Giovanni Paolo II|website=w2.vatican.va|accessdate=21 February 2018}}</ref>
